Well, get ready for a shock, ladies and gentlemen, because it’s back. The chilly, dry days of autumn / winter are a breeding ground for [...]

item.title: Back in Buenos Aires
item.dc:creator: lrntn
item.description: I’ve been home a few days now, from a two week trip to Chile and Argentina.  Or rather, to Chile and Buenos Aires.  I’ll start with the end of my trip, Buenos Aires, mostly because it feels familiar to me by now, like visiting an old friend, and because it was where I spent two [...]
item.content:encoded:
I’ve been home a few days now, from a two week trip to Chile and Argentina.  Or rather, to Chile and Buenos Aires.  I’ll start with the end of my trip, Buenos Aires, mostly because it feels familiar to me by now, like visiting an old friend, and because it was where I spent two months after leaving my job more than two years ago.  And so I’m really fond of the place for that reason alone.  My visit to BsAs almost didn’t happen this time as I planned to travel to Chile only.  But a combination of things, including the fact that my trip would overlap with a friend’s by a few days led to near last minute changes.  Glad it happened this way, that I ended back where I “started”.

It was only four days this time.  Not much seems different, other than a lot of major street work is thankfully gone.  The street art scene is still as vibrant as ever, the women still ever fashionable, the tango music in all its forms still spellbinding.  If this rings of nostalgia, then I admit it.  It seems to be my theme lately, for whatever reason.  And as for me, this time I’ve learned to hoard my coins — the only useful travel tip here (my friends who read my old posts will know what I’m talking about).

For those of you who followed me when I was in Argentina in 2009, you won’t be surprised to see the same theme — street art. Because I’m just so captivated by it. No street tango though, as I mostly stayed away from touristy areas.  And less talk.

Here are a few familiar sights around BsAs.

So what if this is an old likeness.  Maradona — still one of the greatest soccer players ever.

BsAs’ paseaperros – Cesar Milan has got nothing on them !  A great sight every single time.

Some version or other of this facade is on practically every other postcard of BsAs (La Boca) . . . so here we go again.

Also in La Boca, but definitely not on a post card.  ”Neither forget nor forgive” (or some similar translation).   This mural refers to “los desaparecidos” , the tens of thousands of political dissidents and other civilians who “disappeared” during the period of military dictatorship between 1976-83.  Many of the bodies were said to have been disposed in the river in La Boca. 

It was fun to run across this graffiti artwork again this time, as it’s the very first photo I posted from BsAs (here).  It’s a bit surprising that it’s still here and unchanged, as I’m told that even major works get painted over by other artists after two years.

This is Mafalda – a six year old protagonist in popular comic strip that ran from 1964-73, and penned by Argentine cartoonist “Quino”.  Her character is very concerned about humanity and the state of the world, and was apparently well-known worldwide (except for in the US?).  This statue was commissioned by the government of BsAs and installed just over two years ago in San Telmo, where the cartoonist Quino lived.

I’m still sorting through my photos, and will try to find something other than street art, but that could be a difficult task.  Till next time.


Filed under: animals, Argentina, Art, Travel

item.title: Looking for perspective? Visit a big volcano
item.dc:creator: gregmeyer
item.description: Seriously, go look at a Volcano. Ok, some people might not have the privilege (or the unfortunate nearness) of living near a mountain like Mt. St. Helens, but the next time you are nearby, you should go. But why? Geologic Time is Long In the era of “internet time”, where everything changes in nanosecords and [...]
item.content:encoded:
It's bigger than you think

Seriously, go look at a Volcano. Ok, some people might not have the privilege (or the unfortunate nearness) of living near a mountain like Mt. St. Helens, but the next time you are nearby, you should go. But why?

Geologic Time is Long

In the era of “internet time”, where everything changes in nanosecords and it’s tough to remember what you ate for breakfast much less what happened yesterday, visiting a volcano (a still active volcano) like Mt. St. Helens reminds you that our lifespans are very very short in the face of geologic time. The last major eruption of this volcano happened around 1500. The 1980 eruption (which some of us remember) was a blip. Looking at the geologic record provides us with some interesting clues and encourages us to think in much different ways. If you’re interested in thinking about time for the long haul, you might want to check out the 10,000 year clock project.

Nature Doesn’t Care What You Want

Although we clearly influence and change the scape of the planet, the sheer scope, scale, and speed of the changes that can happen in the face of an eruption like the one at Mt. St. Helens dwarf any changes that you or I might try to make on the planet’s course. That doesn’t mean we should give up on our individual efforts – but what it does mean is that the planet can be fickle. In the 1980 eruption, enough material was displaced to fill almost three quarters of a cubic mile. That’s a lot of stuff. See more details about the 1980 eruption here.

It’s Awesome

The sheer scale of the mountain is amazing. You can see Mt. St. Helens for miles on the approach to the Johnson Ridge Observatory (accessed from WA state 504), and yet it still is an incredible site to see. The photo above was taken a Johnson Ridge, about 5 and a half miles away from the Volcano and at an elevation of about 4200 feet (the mountain is around 8,000 feet in height.) Looking at Mt. St. Helens from that distance, you feel as if you’re facing it square on, yet can see the vast influence the mountain had on the surrounding valley when it erupted 31 short years ago.

Of course, Mt. St. Helens isn’t the only interesting natural wonder out there. But it’s a pretty cool one, and I’m amazed to think that I hadn’t been there and had driven past the general area tens or hundreds of times before I decided to go. And I’m glad I did.

item.title: Reflections of the day – Mercedes Benz 300SL
item.dc:creator: digitaldtour
item.description: With the cancellation of this weeks Cars &Coffee / Irvine event (due to facility maintenance being performed on one of the site buildings), I had the opportunity to sit back and reflect on the many different makes and models of cars that frequent the event, and that I have had the pleasure of shooting. Next [...]
item.content:encoded:
With the cancellation of this weeks Cars &Coffee / Irvine event (due to facility maintenance being performed on one of the site buildings), I had the opportunity to sit back and reflect on the many different makes and models of cars that frequent the event, and that I have had the pleasure of shooting. Next to photographing Porsches, another favorite subject of mine over my past three years of attendance has been the Mercedes-Benz 300SL.

I first became aware of the Mercedes 300SL back in the early 1960′s. A friend of my fathers owned a 300SL roadster, and I remember seeing him out driving it around town always with the top down. But it was the 300SL gullwing coupe that made an even greater impression. Here was a beautifully styled coupe, abounding  in detail, and with the most magical doors I had ever seen.  Several other details had also made a lasting impression; a steering wheel that hinged down to allow easier access into the driver’s seat, the wide side sills that required sliding over in order to sit in the bucket seats, and an interior design that was stark by today’s standards, yet purpose-built for performance.  I realized that the attention to detail found throughout the 300SL was genetic, and could also be seen in the earlier models, such as my grandfather’s Mercedes  220 A cabriolet. Thus the 300SL gullwing quickly became one of my favorite Mercedes-Benz models, and still is to this day.

So imagine my surprise when I encountered my first 300SL at Cars & Coffee, knowing the rarity of this particular model. Due in part to this events location, and combined with good sunny Southern California weather, there is a strong possibility of seeing at least one 300SL, be it a Gullwing or a Roadster, almost on a weekly basis.

The following photos were taken from my ongoing “reflection study” series,  and highlights  the Mercedes 300SL gullwing and roadster models.

(All photos by the author)

item.title: Guest Post: Ten Can’t Miss National Parks of the American West
item.dc:creator: eriksmithdotcom
item.description: Over the past 10 years, I have been on a quest to visit all of the National Park units of the lower 48 States. I have visited some incredible places, and I have become specifically attached to the National Parks in the Western United States. There are so many parks that are not mentioned in [...]
item.content:encoded:
Over the past 10 years, I have been on a quest to visit all of the National Park units of the lower 48 States. I have visited some incredible places, and I have become specifically attached to the National Parks in the Western United States. There are so many parks that are not mentioned in this post, too. It’s hard to find a National Park, especially in the west, that disappoints.

Big Bend National Park, Texas

Big Bend covers an area of over 800,000 miles of desert and mountains in West Texas. The park is famed for it’s amazing biodiversity, being home to vast numbers of flora and fauna. Despite it’s recent troubles with illegal immigration, the area around the Rio Grande remains beautiful.

Golden Gate National Recreation Area, California

This multi-unit park covers both sides of the entrance to San Francisco Bay. It includes The historic military post, The Presidio, and well as The Marin Headlands. On my recent trip to California, I was captivated by the Marin Headlands section of the park. It is from these hills you can watch the sunset over the Pacific on one side, and the lights of the San Francisco come on over the Golden Gate Bridge on the other side.

Olympic National Park, Washington

West of Seattle, Olympic covers most of the Olympic Peninsula. The park protects the only rainforest region in the continental United States, as well as areas of coast and mountains. It is amazing to be driving along the Pacific Coast and within an hour to be able to visit snow-capped mountains or lush, fern-filled rain forest.

Grand Canyon National Park, Arizona

There is a reason the Grand Canyon is the second most visited National Park and as well-loved a symbol of America as there is. For being a large whole is the earth, there is not a single viewpoint that doesn’t take you breath away. The truly adventurous can hike down to the bottom and back up again in one day, provided they start early and are in exceptional physical shape.

Yellowstone National Park, Wyoming

Yellowstone was the world’s first National Park, and for good reason. It is the most singular area in the United States. It goes beyond the vast valleys and waterfalls and the majestic mountains. The thing that makes Yellowstone so unique is the geysers and other geothermal features.

Crater Lake National Park, Oregon

This lake, formed in the cone of an extinct volcano, never ceases to amaze visitors with it’s unique shade of blue. I was completely taken by the park during my visit in 2005, but during my recent visit in mid-September I found the lake almost completely obscured by smoke from wildfires burning in the western portions of the park.

Zion National Park, Utah

When a park is named after heaven by it’s first explorers, it must be a pretty incredible place, and Zion is. The canyon from which the park takes it’s name is one of a kind, offering so many hiking possibilities that one could spend weeks here and not exhaust all of the possibilities. The hike that is most unique is the Narrows, which requires wading through knee deep water in some places.

Grand Teton National Park, Wyoming

Often overshadowed by Yellowstone to the north,Grand Teton is an incredible park in it’s own right. Rafting the Snake River through the park is an exceptional experience, with bald eagles flying overhead and the backdrop of the grandiose Tetons to the west. For the best views of the mountains, take the winding road up to the viewpoints of Signal Mountain.

Glacier National Park, Montana

Taking the Going-to-the-Sun Road through Glacier might very well be the most scenic road in all of the United States. The road itself is an engineering marvel, cresting over 10,000 above sea level in many places. I am particularly fond of hiking in the high alpine meadow, which a such an distinctive and fragile ecosystem.

Yosemite National Park, California

I was so overcome with my first views of Yosemite Valley from Glacier Point that I was almost reduced to tears. Being down in the valley itself is just a scenic. Waterfalls and lakes dot this glacial landscape. Not to be overshadowed, The Tioga Road, which traverses the park from east to west, is only open during the summer and early fall months.

 

For more National Park & travel related stuff, my blog is On My Feet or In My Mind. Thanks to Elle for the opportunity to write a post while she’s soaking up some rays!

item.title: How to: seize every opportunity {31 Days}
item.dc:creator: Leslie laughs
item.description: Like we talked about yesterday, even if it feels like you have zero extra time, if you look for it, anyone can find little opportunities to create. Maybe not every day, but some days! One small but new-to-you recipe completed is better than nothing. Writing for five minutes is better than writing for zero minutes. [...]
item.content:encoded:
Like we talked about yesterday, even if it feels like you have zero extra time, if you look for it, anyone can find little opportunities to create. Maybe not every day, but some days!

One small but new-to-you recipe completed is better than nothing. Writing for five minutes is better than writing for zero minutes. A handful of photos taken off of your back patio are better than an empty memory card.

Here are some specific life hacks for making time for creative action.

  • Quality time and creative time can be one in the same. Creative action looks different in busy seasons, because we must be faithful to our priorities. Exploring ways to naturally mix creativity into daily life can help with this. I think that one great way to do this is make creative activities part of quality time with your family or friends. A few weeks ago, Garret and I made a photo block together and it was a great combination of his wood-working skills and my photography work. The quality time together was great, and it made me happy to have one of my photos made into an art piece! I’ve also seen friends with kids do this mixing of life and creativity in lots of wonderful ways. Even small things that might seem silly can help us keep our creative and problem-solving muscles in shape!
  • The timer trick. Do you feel like you never have time to write or draw or take pictures? Most folks can find a 10 or 15 minute chunk of time per day to create.Find a comfortable place, set the kitchen timer, and go.
  • Create for a social, ministry, or outreach activity. This is similar to the first point, in that it follows the theme of integration, but this might feel a little riskier. It takes a different sort of bravery to volunteer your creative skills. Examples: plan a scrapbooking party with friends and friends-of-friends; instead of all going out to eat again, organize a pillow-case dress making party with girl friends to benefit a local non-profit; help plan a Compassion letter writing party (I’ve done that – it was a blast!).
  • Always have a notebook. I know this is not at all a new concept, but it’s a big one for me! I hate it when I forget an idea because I didn’t write it down! So, keep a small notebook with you so that when random ideas or stories jump into your mind, you can capture them instead of half-heartedly filing them in your brain.
  • Free write. This is for when you find a pocket of time, but you don’t feel inspired to write about anything in particular. So write about whatever comes to mind. Introspection, poetry, wishes, stream of consciousness—whatever. JUST GO. Write for sake of writing, for the sake of practicing. Practice matters. Discipline is valuable.

 What do you think? What tricks do you use to carve out time for art?

{31 Days of Creativity Babysteps}

item.title: Adventures in Memecrafting
item.dc:creator: robinlatkovich
item.description: A couple months ago, I drew a very silly picture based on a fragment of a late night conversation. This is Steampug.  In the approximate month-and-a-half since Steampug rode his zeppelin into the strange aether of the internet, he has cropped up on a number of sites, including tumblr, where he has received 2,044 loves/reblogs [...]
item.content:encoded:
A couple months ago, I drew a very silly picture based on a fragment of a late night conversation.

This is Steampug.

© 2011 Robin Latkovich, because why the hell not?

 In the approximate month-and-a-half since Steampug rode his zeppelin into the strange aether of the internet, he has cropped up on a number of sites, including tumblr, where he has received 2,044 loves/reblogs (as of yesterday).  This is more than the total hits to date for this website, and probably more people than have seen any one of my “serious” pieces.

So… t-shirts?

item.title: Tulsa State Fair, Friday, October 7.
item.dc:creator: Rachel
item.description: I went out the state fair one last time with my mom, Jan, and my brother, Paul. We try to go together for an afternoon every year, it’s one of my favorite ways to spend time with my family.
item.content:encoded: I went out the state fair one last time with my mom, Jan, and my brother, Paul. We try to go together for an afternoon every year, it’s one of my favorite ways to spend time with my family.
